author: nanook
title: 15 Lessons Money Diarists Learned After Tracking Their Spending
summary: Every Monday, we take a deeper dive into the Money Diaries community. We started by rounding up some of our favorite comments. Later, we asked all of you whom you like (or don't like) to talk to about money. Today, we're sharing lessons that past diarists have learned after tracking their spending.

author: third_watch
title: The Fun Way to Get Americans to Save More
summary: In some ways, that temporary thrill is not much different than the intangible benefits and happiness that people derive from spending on movies, travel, books or other entertainment. But the cruel irony is, playing the lottery entails far steeper costs, averaging a negative 47 percent return, and by appealing to those who can least afford it, it's a behavior that leads to a vicious cycle. Now, there's an ingenious way credit unions, banks and even Wal-Mart Stores (NYSE: WMT) are harnessing the same allure of the lottery to instead encourage low-income populations to start a regular habit of saving. Essentially, they've turned playing the lottery from a vice into a virtue, creating a version of

author: third_watch
title: 5 Low Leverage Stocks That Can Be Part of Your Portfolio
summary: With the Q3 reporting cycle set to gain steam in the coming weeks, it is reasonable to expect that investors will be more attracted to companies with low leverage than high earnings growth.

author: DeltaBravo
title: This is how first-time buyers could be mortgage-free by their early 40s
summary: According to reports, the average age of a first-time buyer these days is 30 with not everyone being prepared to save up for a deposit to buy their own home, preferring instead to spend their money on fancy cars and phones. Its not an ex-local authority property, a flat, a shared equity home or a new build purchased through the Government's Help to Buy scheme - Shanine Land and Darren Noble have bought a four-bedroom detached executive home for £263,000 and have now revealed their money-saving tips for aspiring homeowners. Shanine, who works in retail, said their achievement shows young people working "standard pay jobs" can save to buy their own homes to defy fears they are being priced out of the housing market. Last year, lender Halifax said the average age of a first-time buyer in the UK is 30.

author: captainunderoos
title: How to create automatic savings plan
summary: Do you have a savings account, yet find it difficult to find money to deposit into it? Do you have the best of intentions every month, but find you don't have enough left over after you pay your bills to pay yourself in the form of savings? According to www.thebalance.com, this isn't an uncommon problem — most people find it hard to save. Generally, when you receive income, it is either deposited directly into your current account, or you make the deposit yourself either at the bank, through an Automatic Teller Machine, or via your phone. And then your money heads straight to your current account, so it's available to pay the seemingly endless stream of bills. It's a vicious cycle, and one that's

author: nanook
title: TOP 3 INVESTING MISTAKES – Adam Torres
summary: Investing mistakes are often times avoidable. I have advised clients for well over a decade and certain patterns of mistakes do not have to be endured. Let's think about some of what has been experienced in just the last 15 years. In 2002 the dot-com bubble burst leaving speculators in high flying speculative technology companies holding worthless or severely devalued stock in many cases. The 2008 housing bubble burst stripping the market and investors of billions of dollars. So could some of the pain experienced in these situation have been avoided? Following are what I consider to be the top 3 investing mistakes and how to avoid them. Many times its not an investors investment strategy that

author: DeltaBravo
title: These 4 Choices Can Mess Up Your Financial Future
summary: Why are some people always strapped for cash while others have money in the bank and are maxing out their retirement investments? It's not just about how much money they earn; it's also about the spending decisions they make. As a financial counselor and former caseworker who assisted families in financial crisis, I've seen all kinds of poor financial decision making. After assisting hundreds of families, I can share the top four decisions families made that led to financial crisis. Learn from their mistakes and avoid their financial woes. 1. Taking out a new car loan If you live in an area without public transportation, you may need a car to get around. However, you don't need a brand-new car.

author: DeltaBravo
title: Childhood sweethearts buy home and say anyone can do it
summary: A couple who have bought their first home in their early 20s say anyone can - by avoiding foreign holidays, credit cards and drunken nights out with kebabs. Childhood sweethearts Shanine Land, 22, and Darren Noble, 24, have just paid £263,000 for a detached house - with no help and despite being on low income. It's not a flat, an ex-local authority property, a shared equity home or a new build purchased through the Government's Help to Buy scheme. The couple have taken on a mortgage which will last just 20 years - although they could pay it off in as little as 13. They say anyone can do it - but as long as they watch every penny and stick to a set of strict spending rules. They have holidays

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Meet the Money Makeover Contestants
summary: Follow six ordinary South Africans as they take up the Absa/City Press Money Makeover Challenge and undergo a money makeover boot camp. The next six months will test their resolve and see them confront tough decisions about every aspect of their finances – from whether the fancy car they bought or the business they started is worth the hassle, to whether the lavish wedding they've wanted will put them into debt before they can even enjoy married life. Each candidate has been allocated their own Absa financial adviser, who will help them get their money matters in order and reach their goals. The candidates will be required to complete certain financial tasks and they must to stick to the budgets

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: The Many Virtues of Simplicity
summary: There are at least eight reasons why taking a simple approach to investing is a wise thing to do. You have to understand your investments, even if it’s just at the highest overview level.  If you don’t have that level of understanding, then at some point you will be tempted to change your investments during a period of market duress, and it will likely be a mistake.  Panic never pays.  How to avoid panic?  Knowledge reduces panic.  Whatever the strategy is, follow it in good times and bad.  Understand how bad things can get before you start an investment program.  Make changes if needed when things are calm, not in the midst of terror. You should be able to explain your investment strategy at a basic level, enough that you can convey it to a friend of equal intelligence.  Only then will you know that you truly understand it.  Also, in trying to explain it you will discover whether your investments are truly simple or not.  Does your friend get it, even if he may not want to imitate what you are doing?

author: DeltaBravo
title: Your Money: 4 must-have money conversations
summary: Talking about money with your spouse or family isn't always an easy thing to do. We'd much rather talk about our jobs, hobbies or other interests than get down to the nitty-gritty details of our personal bottom lines. However, if you're trying to stay on top of your finances, these conversations are necessary. It's best to have these conversations early and often. To help get the ball rolling, we've got a list of the most important questions to discuss to make sure you and your spouse are on the same page. WHERE DOES ALL THE MONEY GO? Take a look back at your last month of spending. Whether it's taking a peek at your balanced check book or using online tools like the ones offered by many banks

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: 5 Money Mistakes You're Probably Making Now
summary: Managing your money can feel stressful and complicated, especially since it's important to make the right financial decisions to achieve key goals. Knowing how to manage your money properly involves knowing what you need to do -- like making a financial plan. But it also means knowing what not to do.  Many Americans make the same common money mistakes, and these mistakes can be costly.  To make sure you're not sabotaging your chances for financial success, it's helpful to look at some of the big money mistakes you might be making right now. Here are five common financial faux pas that could be costing you your chances at financial security and that you'll want to be sure to avoid.  1. Not having

author: DeltaBravo
title: Personal finance: 15 smart things you can do with $1,000 right now
summary: Deploying $1,000 in any of these ways (or several of them!) can make a meaningful difference in your life -- financially or otherwise. A thousand dollars might be pocket change or a rounding error to multimillionaires and billionaires, but it's a meaningful sum for the rest of us. Any amount of money that we can save can be put to good use. Here are 15 examples of smart things you can do with $1,000. Depending on your particular situation, some will be more valuable for you than others. Check out these smart ways to spend $1,000 and see which make the most sense for you. 1. Pay off debt First things first. If you're carrying significant debt, especially high-interest rate debt, such as what credit

author: third_watch
title: Safe Debit Card Kids Helps Tweens and Teens with Money
summary: I'm testing out the new Greenlight debit card. It's a great way to give tweens and teens money management tips and start teaching them responsibility. The Greenlight Kids Debit Card is the perfect tool to introduce kids to basic money management tools. I love the parental oversight features, I am able to set limits on where my daughter spends her money and manage how much she spends each week. I think It's the ultimate safe debit card for kids. My daughter is in 7th grade now, she has much more freedom and responsibility. Mr.Momtrends and I have been working hard to give her a strong financial vocabulary, She gets a weekly allowance and has started earning money through babysitting. Before Greenlight,

author: DeltaBravo
title: Why an Emergency Fund Should Be a Top Financial Priority
summary: If you're like most Americans, you have lots of demands on your money. You may have student loans to pay, a down payment to save for, and high interest debt you're trying to pay off.  Prioritizing all of your different financial goals can be difficult, but one of the very first goals to achieve is saving at least some money for an emergency fund.  Around 60% of Americans have less than $500 available for an emergency, despite the fact emergencies happen all the time. Nearly as many Americans -- 45% -- had incurred a major unexpected expense over the prior year, according to a Bankrate survey.   While your ultimate goal should be to have at least three to six months of living expenses in an emergency
